lines.text: George, what are we doing wrong? We can't ride, we can't walk, we can't eat, we can't pray.
Well, we can think. As long as we got our brains, we can think.
Oh, they'll get that too, George. You'll see.

[after hearing George had been offered the Vice-President position]
What did you say, George?
What did I say? What do you think I said?

I don't know, George. I was hoping you would say no. I was hoping you would say that you and your wife don't really belong in New York. That you wanted to live the rest of your life in Ohio. That you never wanted to see a big city again as long as you live. That you didn't want to live here or in, uh, Chicago, or San Francisco, or New Orleans or Paris or any other place where people have to live on top of each other, and they don't have enough room to walk or to breathe or to smile at each other. That you don't want to step on garbage in the streets, or be attacked by dogs or have to give away watches in the middle of your sleep to men in black capes. That you were through traveling on trains that had no place to sit & no food to eat. And you didn't want to fly in airplanes that have no place to land, and no luggage for you when you land there. That you wish you never came here, and the only thing in the world you really wanted was to pick up your wife and carry her to the airport and fly home... and live happily ever after. That's what I was hoping you would say, George.
That's funny... that's what I told him, word for word.
You chased a dog and you beat a horse. You're stronger than you think.
And you're not getting away with anything! I got all your names and your addresses!
My wife can verify that. Gwen?
I can verify that.
Why... why didn't we just stop and explain?
Explain? What I'm doing in the bushes with a little boy? With my hands in his pockets? They'd give me 10-20 years.
Is there anything wrong? I mean, it's over 35 minutes now.
I imagine we've run into some bad weather.
You don't have to imagine. Just look out the window.
George, now I-I promised I would call the children this morning. If they don't hear from me, they will be worried.
Well, right now they're eating a big bowl of Rice Krispies and bananas. Worry about us, will you?
You haven't thought about them once since we left, have you? About their welfare? About their future if anything should happen to us? Have you thought about our children once since we left home?
Yes! In between the mugging and the kidnapping! Now, you gonnna walk, or we gonna stand here and have a PTA meeting?
37,000 policemen in the city of New York! Not one'll come out in the rain!
Here, look, look! Car!
[a car approaches]
Hey! Help! Help!
[the car drives past them barely hitting George]
Ow! I hope you get in trouble someday!
Oh, please, please if there's any justice let Murray get mugged by the man who took my watch.
Thank you very much.
What are you thanking him for - deserting us? Will you stop thanking everybody?
You can't walk with a bleeding foot.
Well I would fly, but New York is fogged in.
George, I can't walk and you can't carry me. And there are no buses, or taxis, and no car is going to stop to pick up bleeding strangers.
It's not safe in the park at night.
We have already been robbed and kidnapped. We have nothing to lose but four cents. Please, George.
Suppose it rains again?
I am so wet now, it can only make me drier.
Uh, are there any seats on this train? huh?
[the conductor shakes his head "no"]
Oh, well don't you have anything in the parlor car or compartment or anything? I'll pay for it.
This train runs empty six nights a week exept when the New York airport is fogged in, then they fly 'em up to Boston and we could use four more cars.
Well why don't you put on four more cars?
Ain't got four more cars. Noboby takes the train anymore. Everyone is in a hurry.
You expect us to stand all the way to New York?
Not if you give me $11.00 each.
[George pays the fares]
Is there a dining car?
Just sandwiches and drinks. The next car forward.
You know how long we were in line?
Two hours.
Two hours. That's how long.

[hands a plate of food and coffee to a customer]
Chicken sandwich and coffee.
lines.character: Waiter in Dining Car on Train

lines.text: Can we see a menu, please?
We just got sandwiches and drinks.
lines.character: Waiter in Dining Car on Train

lines.text: Oh. Eh, two Chicken sandwiches, please.
Sorry, no chicken.
lines.character: Waiter in Dining Car on Train

lines.text: Isn't that chicken?
Yeah, that's chicken. But when he eats that, that's the end of the chicken.
lines.character: Waiter in Dining Car on Train

lines.text: They're out of chicken, George.
Got ham or cheese?
No ham.
lines.character: Waiter in Dining Car on Train

lines.text: Just cheese.
No cheese.
lines.character: Waiter in Dining Car on Train

lines.text:
[under his breath]
No cheese.
What DO you have?
Peanut Butter on white bread.
lines.character: Waiter in Dining Car on Train

lines.text: What else you got?
More peanut butter on white bread. Ran out of everything a few minutes ago, ma'am.
lines.character: Waiter in Dining Car on Train

lines.text: But don't you have anything else? My husband isn't allowed to eat peanut butter or white bread.
I got saltine crackers and green olives. That's all, ma'am. We didn't expect 350 people tonight. No, ma'am.
lines.character: Waiter in Dining Car on Train

lines.text: You folks live out of town?
Oh yes.
You're lucky.
00, I'd start praying for my job.
Listen, the minute this is over, I want both your badge numbers! I'm through being intimidated!

I was going to take you to dinner at one of the best restaurants in the world. Here you are eating peanut butter on white bread with nothing to drink. If you ever get your mouth open again, I wouldn't blame you if you never talk to me.
Oh my God!
What's wrong?
I lost my left eyelash!
Tell him where you slept last night, hmm? Tell him what you had for breakfast. See how safe he feels.
I'm suing 'em all. I don't care if I'm in court all year.
I'm through carrying pocketbooks in this city. You got a pocketbook, you're a marked woman.
[George is reluctant to help a lost child]
George, I don't know what's happened to you, I've never seen you like this before.
I never saw you wearing my shoes before, but we're in trouble.
Don't pull! Please don't pull! Oh my God, my straps are broken!
You got a wallet?
Uh, no, no wallet. Just the cash. I never carry a wallet.
Give him your wallet, George!
[to Murray]
It's in his left pocket!
My husband and I haven't eaten or slept since yesterday morning!
[the taxicab barely arrives at the Longview Rail stop in time for the train to depart for Grand Central Station]
Just made it. You better rush.
lines.character: Barney Polacek, Cab Driver in Boston

lines.text: How much is that?
Four-fifty, but I still can't break a 20.
lines.character: Barney Polacek, Cab Driver in Boston

lines.text: All right, that's $2.00 from before plus $4.50 is $6.50, plus a dollar tip is $7.50. That's $12.50. You still gotta mail me. You got the address?
Twin Oaks, Ohio. 1174 Kellerman La...
lines.character: Barney Polacek, Cab Driver in Boston

lines.text:
[furious]
No, I'M Kellerman! Willow Tree Lane! 1174 Willow Tree Lane!

[yells]
George! George, he's got it. Come on!
He hasn't got it! All he's got is my $20.
[George and Gwen rush the board the train as it's departing]
I don't get my $12.50, you're gonna hear from me!
Barney Polacek! 391 Clancy Street, Boston, Massachusetts! Zip Code 02124!
lines.character: Barney Polacek, Cab Driver in Boston

lines.text:
[out of breath]
He said Benny or Bernie? I don't know.
[George and Gwen finally made it to the Waldorf-Astoria]
Excuse me.
Yes?
Mr. & Mrs. Kellerman, Twin Oaks, Ohio. We finally got here. Ha-ha.
Do you have reservation?
Yeah, made by the Drexel Company through the Hilton Reservation Service.
In Twin Oaks, Ohio.
You must be pretty busy putting people up in the lobby.
Oh, it's the least we can do. With this transit strike, most of them have no way to get home, and there's not a room in this city tonight.
Oh, that's very nice of you.
Ah, here we are. George Kellerman?
That's it, Yeah. I hope you got a nice, big, dry bed.
And a drug store open. I have to get an eyelash and tape for my ankles.

[Since Murray the mugger made off with the key, George can't open his locked suitcase]
Can't you break it open with a knife?
Do you know what that suitcase is called, huh? "Diplomatic Courier." It's for couriers with important papers for diplomats. Can't get it open with a hand grenade!
How about a locksmith?
In 17 minutes? He'd have to feed me and shave me while he's opening the suitcase. Well, it's the last time that I buy good luggage, I tell you. Never again. Never again!
[bangs futilely on his suitcase]
